top_comment.text:
The classical physics that we encounter in our everyday, macroscopic world 
is very different from the quantum physics that governs systems on a much 
smaller scale (like atoms). One great example of quantum physics’ weirdness 
can be shown in the Schrödinger's cat thought experiment. Josh Samani walks 
us through this experiment in quantum entanglement.﻿
top_comment.author: TED-Ed

ways probability and the spins of electrons are connected which is by 
photonic exchanges. This video is truly awful. The whole point in his 
thinking was to demonstrate the effect of atomic halflives and their 
relation to an observers relative information. His equations are good for 
quantum effects and the cat is just an over simplification not a "fact". 
This Video makes it seem like a many worlds interpretation. awfully 
confusing. The orginal thought experiment relies on halflives of atomic 
decay, connected to a bomb which makes a HUGE impact on the understanding 
of this postulate. They make taking a cat to the ends of the universe look 
like baking bread, and you couldnt entangle two cats to begin with because 
of the debroigle wavelength anyways, at least not with current physics. 
This video angered me to the core

comments.text:
I am also a non-scientist. And I was not trying to be self-righteous or 
pedantic. The purpose of any experiment is to test a hypothesis or to 
demonstrate a principle. Schrodinger's cat is a really interesting thought 
experiment. Perhaps it was intended as an analogy for the Copenhagen 
interpretation of quantum mechanics. As for the purpose of science, 
"Physics is like sex.  It may have some practical results, but that's not 
why we do it". BTW, where did I imply that your question was "oblivious to 
the scientific endeavor"?
comments.author: Kishore Gopalakrishnan

comments.text:
So, does my question seem at all oblivious to the scientific endeavor? 
Please explain. Don't be glib. Don't act self-righteous. Educate me, a 
non-scientist, about the purposes of Mr. Schrodinger's experiment. What are 
the practical implications of such a vacuous experiment, and forgive any 
appearance of cynicism on my part. It's unintentional, thanks.
comments.author: Richard Salvador

comments.text:

Is Schrödinger's cat a good analogy? I mean, if we place detectors inside 
the boxes we can know with certainty whether the cat's alive or dead at any 
time so we don't have to worry about it being in half state. Is it because 
we lack the knowledge on how quantum objects move that we're relying on 
probability?﻿

I believe Einstein tried to reason this out. But I would have to conclude 
that there is a realm of super positions that is proximate to time and 
space which passes wave functions to and fro. This may seem psychologically 
impossible, but perhaps not mathematically impossible. The physical 
distance which we consider large from our perspective might be microscopic 
in the realm of all possibilities. Perhaps another way to look at it is 
that a set of possible outcomes does not qualify as information and can 
never have a probability of one.

comments.author: Blake Young

comments.text:
+Blake Young Well, it actually isn't decided when the lid is being closed, 
that is a slight misconception that arises from the analogy in the video. 
In quantum mechanics the actual "collapse of the wave function" as it is 
called, happens when the particle is OBSERVED. What this means is that the 
particle is in two (or more) states at the same time until a measurement is 
made.
comments.author: kaddru

comments.text:

information is being transferred at the next measurement. We are measuring 
something that was decided when the lid was closed. Please help me 
understand this.
comments.author: Blake Young

comments.text:
mesure the total spin of two particles and when you then mesure their 
individual spins it must add up to the total. However the two particles 
spins are individual random but will always come out to add up to the 
corect total. So for instance, if two particles together have 0 spin then 
one particle must have spin 1 and the other spin -1 (this might corospond 
to spinning clockwise or counter clockwise). The total must be 0 and 1 + 
(-1) =0. But its random which will have spin 1 and which will have spin -1. 
So until you measure one of them each particle could be either 1 or -1 but 
once you mesure one of them you now know that it is 1 and the other is -1 
or the reverse. This is true no matter how far apart they were seperated.

comments.text:
+Rev0lutionIsMyName I can answer your question about the "instantaneous 
communication". The laws of general relativity indeed forbid instantaneous 
communication, but this is not what happen when two entangled electrons 
choose opposite spins. Why? Because it is not possible to send any 
information with this entanglement. Therefore causality can never be 
violated. The only thing that is transferred instantaneously is some 
"quantum information" but this does not violate any laws of nature.

Also I hate it when people make up some theory about the universe then 
claim it's true "because quantum mechanics!" and sell books where they 
explain this stuff. It is not science! It is a misinterpretation of 
science, deliberately used to sell an idea.

necessary to explain the phenomenon of entanglement which is false.

Well I did explain it to you. Light speed is the limit at which information 
can travel in our universe and that's it.

say instead "information can't travel faster than light". That doesn't make 
much a difference because almost everything (matter and energy) carry 
information.

it doesn't break the speed of light.

You have every right to believe that the universe is self-aware. But there 
is nothing in quantum mechanics that is even remotely related with 
consciousness.

comments.text:
+Tobias Beer Of course quantum mechanics is not as clear cut as classical 
mechanics is simply because no one can see what's going on at such scales.

If you want a specific experiment about quantum mechanics, look up the 
double slit experiment. This experiment proves the wave-particle duality 
which can only be explained with quantum mechanics. You can also see the 
Heisenberg uncertainty principle at work in this experiment.
comments.author: Jeremie Venne

comments.text:
//Experiments about quantum mechanics have been tested and the results they 
gave were what QM predicted. In that sense, you can say that QM is true and 
has been proven and is the strongest theory that explains physical 
phenomena at nanoscopic scales.//

This statement is so generalized that it simply doesn't live up to the 
reality of the matter at all.

Quantum mechanics on the small scale is not at all such a clear cut case 
such as classical mechanics on the grand scale.

Therefore, without talking any specific experiments, as to the so called 
proof they are to provide or conclusions you say they allow *you* to make 
...you could as well be selling me Star Wars, literally.
comments.author: Tobias Beer

comments.text:
+Tobias Beer Experiments about quantum mechanics have been tested and the 
results they gave were what QM predicted. In that sense, you can say that 
QM is true and has been proven and is the strongest theory that explains 
physical phenomena at nanoscopic scales.

Now, is it truly how things behave at such scales? No one really knows, but 
so far, QM is the best we have to explain it.

Just like when Einstein's theory of relativity came out, a lot of people 
thought it was the work of a mad man, yet it still holds true to this day.
comments.author: Jeremie Venne

comments.text:
+Michiel Van Kets It is accurate, extremely. It can predict the chance of 
certain events occurring with higher accuracy than you can imagine and if 
you don't understand QM I suggest you study it because there's absolutely 
nothing wrong with QM and the theory doesn't have to change at all 
actually. Your belief that an equation must give a singular value to be 
valid shows you don’t understand mathematics or science very well and only 
because an equation gives a chance instead of one certain outcome doesn’t 
make it cheating in quantum mechanics, classical mechanics, chemistry or 
even biology. Consider elementary calculations in chemistry which only 
consider ideal conditions such as 100% conversion of substances and 
idealized equilibrium and so on meaning if it was actually applied to an 
actual situation it would definitely not be exact or in genetics where 
Hardy Weinberg’s equation is entirely statistical in nature meaning it only 
calculates average changes. Continue studying and you will see most science 
is not exact. If you use quantum mechanics you will get extremely exact 
chances of events happening which have absolutely no apparent deterministic 
cause and the chances can be 50-50 or they can be 0.999-0.001 with much 
more than 3 significant digits.
You assert 1), 2) is illogical and haven't mentioned anything about 3) so 
I’m entirely unconvinced.

comments.text:
If one electron finds itself in a magnetic field, it can precess, losing 
its original orientation.  But the second electron, a light year away, will 
not.  And thus the correlation between the two spins would be lost.  That's 
just one way to spoil the entanglement.  If it was very easy to keep two 
spatially distant particles in an entangled state, it would be done by now. 
 The fact that this requires heroic efforts to experimentally measure is an 
indication of how tenuous most entangled states are.
comments.author: Jim Kakalios

comments.text:
Thank you, Jim. I wasn't aware that the entanglement was so easily 
disturbed even if they are *not* measured. Is this what you are saying?
comments.author: johnny conner

comments.text:
You are correct - provided that the wave function is not disturbed.  Think 
about the two-particle wave function as an infinitely stretchy ribbon 
connecting the two electrons.  Extending the ribbon a length of a 
light-year is possible, but  it is also possible that something could 
interact with the ribbon, in essence breaking the connection between the 
two particles.  The point is - it is $%&#@! hard to keep the two particles 
entangled over long distances, which is why I think Anton Zeilinger's 
experiments (using photons) at Vienna will win the Nobel Prize in Physics 
some day.  (If it happens this fall, then I called it, but I have been 
calling it for Zeilinger for the past few years, so not as impressive).
comments.author: Jim Kakalios

comments.text:
Very good description of this phenomenon, +Jim Kakalios. Thank you for you 
illucidations. And isn't it true that once they are entangled, this state 
will be disrupted in one if it is measured, and the other will respond in 
kind *even if they are separated by **any** distance in space and time,* 
even across the galaxy (or farther)?
comments.author: johnny conner

comments.text:
One has to carefully prepare the initial state.  You have two electrons, 
for example, one being spin up and the other being spin down.  If they 
start off very far apart, there is no entanglement, as I can tell which one 
is on the right and which is on the left.  But if they are so close that 
their wave functions overlap, then as they are identical, I can not 
distinguish which is on the left and which is on the right.  NOW they are 
entangled, and described by a two particle wave function.  If I now move 
them apart, they are still described by a two-particle wave function, as 
long as I don't interact with either particle.  Now if I perform a 
measurement on one electron, determining that it is spin up, this also 
tells me that the other electron is spin down.  More than obvious logic (if 
I start with two marbles, black and white, and check to see that one is 
black, then the other must be white), I also, by doing a measurement on one 
electron, determine the axis in which "up" and "down" is defined!  This 
information is transmitted to the second electron, as the two particles are 
part of the same wave function.  This is the 'spooky action at a distance,' 
and great care must be taken to avoid messing with the electrons until you 
are ready to do the measurement (that is, to avoid decoherence).  Sorry 
this is long.
comments.author: Jim Kakalios

comments.text:
+Jim Kakalios
Yes? How *is* the entanglement accomplished, btw...?
comments.author: johnny conner

comments.text:
Hmmm.  Glides right by how one actually prepares an entangled state (which 
is central to understanding what it is) nor any consideration to the 
efforts to avoid decoherence at large separations.  Reminds me of a Brian 
Cox video.
comments.author: Jim Kakalios

comments.text:
It's because you're trying to learn it from a video meant for entertainment 
for people who most likely have not taken any math or physics classes 
beyond high school or first year of university (you only really get into 
modern physics starting your second year, at least if you do you undergrad 
physics degree in Canada).

There's a lot of background information that they left out of this video on 
how modern physics developed, and more importantly, they didn't even 
mention any of the mathematics behind it (if you ever try to learn physics 
without doing any math, you're doing it wrong; physics is quantitative 
subject, not a qualitative one). It makes more sense when you really look 
at how this was all discovered or proposed (check out any modern physics 
textbook if you are interested) starting from the early 20th, century.

Physicists and other scientists don't just sit around all day making this 
stuff up in their heads out of nowhere. There were a lot of experiments 
done that they weren't able to explain, and in order to do so they had to 
develop all of the modern physics you see today, using the scientific 
method.
comments.author: Paulelele

comments.text:
To get a better picture of Quantum Mechanics, I suggest you to study Modern 
Physics first, for example, the Black Body radiation phenomena and the 
Photoelectric Effect, that were among the first phenomena that needed 
Quantum Mechanics concepts to be explained. There are several other 
experiments on Quantum Mechanics that don't require knowledge on quantum 
states, superposition of states or this kind of stuff at all, yet they 
still emphasizes QM properties.

comments.author: Isaiah Paradiso

comments.text:
+Isaiah Paradiso Actually, I'll clarify a bit.  You're not actually 
transmitting data faster than the speed of light because no data is 
actually transferred.  You're simply inferring data from observing effects 
from an electron spin from another entangled particle far away.  However, 
the net observation of observing this spin is you could use it as a digital 
transmitter.
comments.author: Isaiah Paradiso

comments.text:
Yes.  This is the concept behind a zero latency radio.  Theoretically 
speaking you could entangle two electrons and put one on a space ship a 
light year away and another on earth.  You could then toggle the spin of 
one electron, triggering the alternate spin of the entangled electron a 
light year away.  This creates a binary signal.  Encode you data into this 
binary signal and you have faster than light data transmission.  Of course, 
it's not a free lunch.  You still needed to park a spaceship a light year 
away in the first place.  

There's other theories that you could use entangled particles to create a 
transporter using a similar technique.
comments.author: Isaiah Paradiso

We don't know what force allows for entanglement yet, check back in a few 
years. As for spin you are making a mistake based on ignorance, in quantum 
mechanics 'spin' is a term for the particles state, it can spin up (high 
energy) or spin down (low energy). The actual direction of the spin is 
meaningless as it's not spinning like a top, its just a label for one of 
two states. Lastly there totally is a way to control particle spin, many 
ways in fact, usually a laser is used to add or burn away energy from the 
particle. Communicating instantaneously is precisely the reason we are 
looking into QET devices.

comments.author: Anshul katta

comments.text:
Close but not fully true... poison kills the cat but that is set off by a 
chain reaction of a radioactive element decaying...

Schrödinger's cat: a cat, a flask of poison, and a radioactive source are 
placed in a sealed box. If an internal monitor detects radioactivity (i.e. 
a single atom decaying), the flask is shattered, releasing the poison that 
kills the cat. The Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics implies 
that after a while, the cat is simultaneously alive and dead. Yet, when one 
looks in the box, one sees the cat either alive or dead, not both alive and 
dead. This poses the question of when exactly quantum superposition ends 
and reality collapses into one possibility or the other.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schr%C3%B6dinger's_cat

works on the microscopic level and not the Macroscopic level like cats and 
bombs. On a microscopic level, take 2 identical atoms of the same element, 
their electrons will spin around the nucleus. In quantum physics, it is 
safe to say that the position of the electron will never be in the same 
position or opposite position. However, if you freeze atom A, it is safe to 
say that whenever you freeze Atom B it will never be in the same position 
or opposite position of atom A.

I'm all for simplifying whenever possible but that has got to be the most 
basic way to explain Schrodinger's cat... but whatever it's technically 
correct.﻿
top_comment.author: Hatori Inukai

comments.text: +Felds Liscia No problem :)
comments.author: Hatori Inukai

comments.text:
+keltzar1 I think the Stern-Gerlach experiment is good to talk about spin 
and how sequential measurements of its components affect each other 
(Heisenberg uncertainty), and the Photoelectric Effect to talk about the 
quantization of energy.
comments.author: Rafael Feliczaki

comments.text:
+Rafael Feliczaki The double slit experiment should really get more 
publicity that Schrodinger's cat but I guess it doesn't have that element 
of easy to understand strangeness.
comments.author: keltzar1

comments.text:
I'm not sure if explaining Schrodinger's cat is even useful, for me, I 
always thought is caused more confusion than enlightenment. Maybe it is 
better to explain actual QM experiments instead.
comments.author: Rafael Feliczaki

comments.text: good job here on the comments. thanks for helping educating people! :)
comments.author: Felds Liscia

top_comment.text: Plot twist! We are the cats﻿
top_comment.author: The Cake is not a Vlog

comments.text: Precisely!
comments.author: The Cake is not a Vlog

comments.text:
No plot twist at all... this concept applies to everything in our lives: 
information only has a real value when measured.
comments.author: Matheus Adorni Dardenne

captions.text:
Consider throwing a ball
straight into the air.

Can you predict the motion
of the ball after it leaves your hand?
Sure, that's easy.

The ball will move upward
until it gets to some highest point,

then it will come back down
and land in your hand again.
Of course, that's what happens,

and you know this because you have
witnessed events like this countless times.

You've been observing the physics
of everyday phenomena your entire life.

But suppose we explore a question
about the physics of atoms,
like what does the motion of an electron

around the nucleus of a 
hydrogen atom look like?

Could we answer that question based on
our experience with everyday physics?
Definietly not. Why?

Because the physics that governs the
behavior of systems at such small scales

is much different than the physics
of the macroscopic objects
you see around you all the time.
The everyday world you know and love

behaves according to the laws 
of classical mechanics.
But systems on the scale of atoms

behave according to the laws 
of quantum mechanics.

This quantum world turns out to be
a very strange place.

An illustration of quantum strangeness
is given by a famous thought experiment:
Schrödinger's cat.

A physicist, who doesn't particularly 
like cats, puts a cat in a box,

along with a bomb that has a 50% chance
of blowing up after the lid is closed.

Until we reopen the lid,
there is no way of knowing
whether the bomb exploded or not,

and thus, no way of knowing
if the cat is alive or dead.

In quantum physics,
we could say that before our observation
the cat was in a superposition state.

It was neither alive nor dead but
rather in a mixture of both possibilities,
with a 50% chance for each.

The same sort of thing happens
to physical systems at quantum scales,

like an electron orbiting
in a hydrogen atom.
The electron isn't really orbiting at all.

It's sort of everywhere in space,
all at once,

with more of a probability of being
at some places than others,

and it's only after 
we measure its position

that we can pinpoint where it is
at that moment.

A lot like how we didn't know
whether the cat was alive or dead
until we opened the box.

This brings us to the strange
and beautiful phenomenon
of quantum entanglement.

Suppose that instead of one cat in a box,
we have two cats in two different boxes.

If we repeat the Schrödinger's cat experiment
with this pair of cats,

the outcome of the experiment
can be one of four possibilities.

Either both cats will be alive,
or both will be dead,

or one will be alive 
and the other dead, or vice versa.

The system of both cats
is again in a superposition state,

with each outcome having a 25% chance
rather than 50%.
But here's the cool thing:

quantum mechanics tells us
it's possible to erase

the both cats alive and both cats dead
outcomes from the superposition state.

In other words,
there can be a two cat system,

such that the outcome will always be
one cat alive and the other cat dead.

The technical term for this is that the
states of the cats are entangled.

But there's something truly mindblowing
about quantum entanglement.

If you prepare the system of two cats
in boxes in this entangled state,

then move the boxes to opposite 
ends of the universe,

the outcome of the experiment
will still always be the same.

One cat will always come out alive,
and the other cat will always end up dead,

even though which particular cat
lives or dies is completely undetermined
before we measure the outcome.
How is this possible?

How is it that the states of cats
on opposite sides of the universe
can be entangled in this way?

They're too far away to communicate
with each other in time,

so how do the two bombs always 
conspire such that
one blows up and the other doesn't?
You might be thinking,

"This is just some theoretical
mumbo jumbo.

This sort of thing can't happen
in the real world."
But it turns out that quantum entanglement

has been confirmed in 
real world lab experiments.

Two subatomic particles entangled
in a superposition state,

where if one spins one way
then the other must spin the other way,

will do just that,
even when there's no way

for information to pass
from one particle to the other

indicating which way to spin
to obey the rules of entanglement.

It's not surprising then that
entanglement is at the core
of quantum information science,

a growing field studying how to use
the laws of the strange quantum world
in our macroscopic world,

like in quantum cryptography, so spies
can send secure messages to each other,

or quantum computing,
for cracking secret codes.

Everyday physics may start to look
a bit more like the strange quantum world.

Quantum teleportation 
may even progress so far,

that one day your cat will 
escape to a safer galaxy,

where there are no physicists
and no boxes.

title: What can Schrödinger's cat teach us about quantum mechanics? - Josh Samani
